citations.narrative:
Kennel number 1 features 11 weaned puppies from 3 litters, all under 16 weeks of age, identified by cage cards rather
than the methods prescribed by this section. Deviations in puppy identification may compromise tracking of individual
puppies on the premises. The facility must identify weaned puppies less than 16 weeks of age by an official tag as
described in section 2.51, an Administrator-approved tattoo marking, or an Administrator-accepted plastic-type collar
displaying the information required by section 2.51.
Correct by March 4, 2025.

While the facility's written Program of Veterinary Care directs administration of ectoparasite prevention to adult dogs
monthly between April and November, the facility has been administering it less frequently during these times. Deviation
from the approved parasite prevention schedules may increase risk of parasitism, especially during months with
potentially higher exposure risk. Facility parasite control practices must adhere to a program authorized by the Attending
Veterinarian.
Correct by March 14, 2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.50(a)(2) 
   
Time and method of identification. 
Kennel number 1 features 11 weaned puppies from 3 litters, all under 16 weeks of age, identified by cage cards rather 
than the methods prescribed by this section. Deviations in puppy identification may compromise tracking of individual 
puppies on the premises. The facility must identify weaned puppies less than 16 weeks of age by an official tag as 
described in section 2.51, an Administrator-approved tattoo marking, or an Administrator-accepted plastic-type collar 
displaying the information required by section 2.51. 
 
Correct by March 4, 2025. 
3.13(a)(3) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
While the facility's written Program of Veterinary Care directs administration of ectoparasite prevention to adult dogs 
monthly between April and November, the facility has been administering it less frequently during these times. Deviation 
from the approved parasite prevention schedules may increase risk of parasitism, especially during months with 
potentially higher exposure risk. Facility parasite control practices must adhere to a program authorized by the Attending 
Veterinarian.  
 
Correct by March 14, 2025. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative. 
 
 n
